title: What’s driving Alzheimer’s disease?
content: Alzheimer’s disease is driven by genetics, metabolic health, vascular health, inflammation, and toxins.

title: The genetic component
content: Alzheimer’s disease has a strong genetic component. ApoE4 is the most important gene in terms of understanding risk. TOMM40 may also be relevant. However, a small percentage of AD cases (about 1%) are due to “deterministic” genes such as Amyloid precursor protein (APP), PSEN1, and PSEN2.

title: Metabolic Health component of Alzheimer’s disease
content: Metabolic health is a common thread that links all chronic diseases, including Alzheimer’s disease.

title: Vascular component to Alzheimer’s disease
content: Vascular health is a huge component of Alzheimer’s disease.

title: Inflammatory component to Alzheimer’s disease
content: Inflammation is an enormous component of Alzheimer’s disease.

title: Toxins related to Alzheimer’s disease
content: Toxins are almost assuredly a component that revolves around Alzheimer’s disease.

title: Blood tests for the deterministic genes
content: Deterministic genes such as PSEN1, PSEN2, and APP can be tested for pretty easily. However, that’s usually just to confirm a strong suspicion after seeing a strong family history of getting AD.

title: The punchline when it comes to Alzheimer’s disease
content: We get pretty darn good information from the blood. We get the relevant genes, all the vascular stuff, and all the metabolic stuff. We can’t get as much good info about the inflammatory stuff, and we’re pretty bad at getting the toxins because truthfully we just don’t know. But overall we get a pretty darn good way to handicap someone’s risk of Alzheimer’s disease.
